definition: Land includes the earth surface, subsoil, and all things naturally attached to it such as trees and minerals. Under Nigerian law, land ownership and usage are governed primarily by the Land Use Act of 1978.
A Nigerian law enacted in 1978 to centralize the control and administration of land. It vests all land in each state (except federal land) in the State Governor to hold in trust for the people.
A legal right granted by a State Governor allowing a person to use land for a specific purpose under terms and conditions. It is usually issued with a Certificate of Occupancy.
A right granted by the local government to use land in accordance with local customary law, often for agricultural, residential, or grazing purposes in non-urban areas.
An official document issued by the Governor confirming a person’s right to occupy and use a portion of land under a statutory right of occupancy.
Under the Act, the Governor of a State holds all land in that state (not under federal control) in trust for the people and has the power to allocate land and issue statutory rights of occupancy.
Any person lawfully occupying land under a right of occupancy or customary law, including a sub-lessee or sub-underlessee of a holder.
Any area designated as such by the Governor under the Land Use Act. Different legal regimes apply in urban areas compared to rural or non-urban areas.
Permanent structures or modifications made to land such as buildings, fences, wells, and roads that increase the land's utility or value. These may qualify for compensation if the land is revoked.
The power of the Governor or local government to cancel a right of occupancy, typically for overriding public interest or failure to comply with land use regulations. Compensation may be payable.

title: Definition: Estate in Land
content: An estate in land represents the degree, nature, and extent of a person’s interest in land. It can be legal or equitable and may exist in freehold or leasehold form.

title: Types of Estate
content:
1. Freehold: Ownership of land for an indefinite period.
2. Leasehold: Right to use and occupy land for a fixed period.
3. Life estate: Interest for the duration of a person's life.

title: Historical Evolution of Land Law in Nigeria
content: Before 1978, land was governed by a mix of English common law and customary law. The Land Use Act of 1978 was introduced to unify land ownership under state control and to simplify acquisition and administration of land.

title: Statute: Land Use Act 1978 (Section 1)
content: All land in a state is vested in the Governor of that state to be held in trust for the use and benefit of all Nigerians.

title: Statute: Land Use Act 1978 (Section 5)
content: The Governor has the power to grant statutory rights of occupancy over urban land.

title: Statutory Right of Occupancy
content: Granted by the state Governor to individuals or companies, conferring the right to use and occupy land for a term (usually 99 years).

title: Customary Right of Occupancy
content: Granted by local governments, often in rural areas, based on native law and customs. It does not always require formal documentation.

title: Case: Ogunola v. Eiyekole (1990)
content: The court upheld that customary land tenure is recognized and enforceable, provided it is not in conflict with statutory laws.

title: Certificate of Occupancy (C of O)
content: Issued under Section 9 of the Land Use Act to provide legal proof of a person’s right to occupy land. It applies to both statutory and customary rights.

title: Co-ownership of Land
content: Occurs when two or more persons hold legal or equitable interest in the same land. It may be joint tenancy or tenancy in common. Co-owners have undivided interests.

title: Case: Bamgbose v. Daniel (1958)
content: Court held that co-ownership implies equal right to possession, and no co-owner can claim exclusive ownership of any part without partition.

title: Alienation of Land
content: Means the transfer of rights in land (e.g., sale, gift, lease). Under Section 22 of the Land Use Act, Governor’s consent is required before any alienation.

title: Case: Savannah Bank v. Ajilo (1989)
content: Held that any transaction involving land without the required Governor’s consent is null and void, even if between private individuals.

title: Compulsory Acquisition
content: The government can acquire land for public purposes under Section 28 of the Land Use Act, but must pay compensation and follow due process.

title: Case: Bello v. Diocesan Synod of Lagos (1973)
content: Held that lawful compulsory acquisition requires prompt and adequate compensation to the affected person.

title: Governor’s Powers Under Land Use Act
content: The Governor may grant or revoke rights of occupancy, consent to alienation, and control land allocation within a state. This is exercised under Section 1 and Section 28 of the Act.

title: Laches and Acquiescence
content: Laches refers to unreasonable delay in asserting a right. Acquiescence implies silent approval of an act. Both can bar a land claim if the landowner has failed to act promptly.

title: Case: Akpan Awo v. Cookey Gam (1913)
content: Plaintiff lost land rights due to prolonged silence while the defendant openly occupied and developed the land. The court applied laches and acquiescence.

title: Meaning of Land in Customary Law
content: Under customary law, land is held communally by families or communities. Individual use is allowed, but outright ownership is rare without family consent.

title: Case: Amodu Tijani v. Secretary, Southern Nigeria (1921)
content: Privy Council recognized that under customary law, ownership belongs to the family or community, not an individual.

definition: Land includes the physical surface of the earth, everything above it (airspace), everything below it (subsoil), and fixtures attached to it.
statute_reference: Land Use Act 1978, Section 1; Interpretation Act

key_cases.case_name: Amodu Tijani v Secretary, Southern Nigeria (1921)
key_cases.facts: Dispute over compensation for land compulsorily acquired by the colonial government.
key_cases.decision: The Privy Council recognized native land title and the need for compensation.

legal_analysis: The legal conception of land in Nigeria extends beyond just the soil to include fixtures and incorporeal rights. This broad definition underpins land ownership and tenure in both statutory and customary contexts.

definition: A legal right granted by the Governor under the Land Use Act, 1978, for individuals to occupy land for specific purposes.

key_cases.facts: Dispute over the right to use and possess land under statutory grant.
key_cases.decision: The court affirmed that rights of occupancy must be properly obtained from the Governor.

key_cases.facts: Transfer of land without Governor’s consent.
key_cases.decision: The transaction was held void for lack of consent.

legal_analysis: A statutory right of occupancy is essential for proving legal possession. It creates a legal interest that can be transferred or mortgaged with the Governor’s consent.

definition: A right of land occupation granted by a Local Government over non-urban land for residential, agricultural, or other purposes under customary law.

key_cases.case_name: Nkwocha v. Governor of Anambra State (1984) 1 SCNLR 634
key_cases.facts: Challenge to the Governor’s power to revoke a customary right.
key_cases.decision: The Supreme Court upheld the Governor’s powers under the Act.

legal_analysis: Customary rights of occupancy allow for local governance of land but are subject to statutory oversight. They must be exercised consistently with the Land Use Act.

definition: An official document issued by the Governor as evidence of a right of occupancy granted under the Land Use Act.

key_cases.facts: Dispute over the validity of a Certificate of Occupancy.
key_cases.decision: The court held that a C of O is prima facie evidence of title but can be challenged.

legal_analysis: The Certificate of Occupancy provides formal proof of legal title, although it can be contested. It is a key instrument for real estate transactions.

definition: The Governor has statutory power to revoke a right of occupancy for overriding public interest.

key_cases.case_name: Osho v. Foreign Finance Corp (1991) 4 NWLR (Pt. 184) 157
key_cases.facts: Land was revoked without due process.
key_cases.decision: The revocation was declared invalid for failure to follow statutory procedure.

legal_analysis: Revocation must follow due process and must be for public interest. Failure to comply with statutory requirements renders revocation unlawful and liable to compensation.

definition: A person whose right of occupancy is revoked is entitled to compensation based on the value of the unexhausted improvements on the land.

key_cases.case_name: Lagos State Development and Property Corp v. Foreign Finance Corp (1987) 1 NWLR (Pt. 50) 413
key_cases.facts: Refusal to pay compensation for revoked land.
key_cases.decision: The court ruled in favor of the claimant for compensation of improvements.

legal_analysis: Compensation is limited to the value of developments. Bare land value is not compensated, which raises concerns over equity and fairness.

definition: The transfer of interest in land held under a right of occupancy, which requires the Governor’s consent.

key_cases.facts: Attempted mortgage of land without consent.
key_cases.decision: Held void for non-compliance with statutory requirement.

legal_analysis: Alienation without consent renders the transaction void. Consent ensures government oversight and control of land dealings.
